content.label: SECTION
content.heading: Introduction to NPM
copy: NPM (Node Package Manager) is a package manager for Node. Before you can start using NPM, you first have to install Node. To verify that NPM has been installed, open the terminal to confirm the NPM version:
content.label: CODE/MARKUP
SECTION
content.heading: package.json
copy: A package.json file lists all the packages and dependencies your project requires. There are two basic ways to create a package.json file:
The default package.json can be created using the '-y' or '--yes' flag.
content.label: CODE/MARKUP
SECTION
content.heading: Install packages
copy: The install command installs a package, including any packages that it depends on. The packages to be installed will be listed within the package.json file. When the command is used, the installed packages will be installed within a node_modules directory.
content.label: CODE/MARKUP
SECTION
content.heading: Install new packages
copy: When installing a new NPM package, the following command can be used. The new package will be listed within the package.json file and installed within a local node_modules directory.
By default, npm install will install all modules listed as dependencies in the package.json file.
content.label: CODE/MARKUP
SECTION
copy: In global mode (ie, with '-g' or '--global' appended to the command), the installed package will be installed as a global package.
This will allow the package to be used in any location or directory throughout the system.
content.label: CODE/MARKUP
SECTION
content.heading: devDependency
copy: You will install a package as a devDependency if you want to use a package for developers or during development. Grunt, Gulp, or Webpack are examples of packages that would be installed as a devDependency. When distributing your code to production, these dependencies will not be available.
The packages installed will be listed as a devDependency within the package.json file.
content.label: CODE/MARKUP
SECTION
content.heading: Dependency
copy: You will install a package as a Dependency if you want to use a package for distribution/production. Examples may include: React, Redux or Angular.
The packages installed will be listed as a dependency within the package.json file.
content.label: CODE/MARKUP
SECTION
content.heading: Listing Packages
copy: This command will print out all versions of packages installed, as well as their dependencies, in a tree structure inside the terminal.
